required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Blood Flow Restriction Training Combined With Abdominal draw-in Maneuver on Transverse Abdominis Strengthening
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Blood Flow Restriction Training Combined With Abdominal draw-in Maneuver on Transverse Abdominis Strengthening

brief_summary.textblock:
The transverse abdominis (TrA) is the deepest muscle layer of lateral and anterior abdominal wall and also known as a significant component of core stability. Abdominal draw-in maneuver (ADIM) is the main for the strengthening of the deep muscle, however, sufficient activation of TrA by ADIM is limited. Blood flow restriction (BFR) training is a technique combined with low intensity exercise that produces similar results to high intensity training. However, there is few evidences for BFR training on core muscles.
Healthy adults (age ranged 18-34 years and BMI between 18.5~24.99) were randomly recruited in the study. For the intervention group, an inflatable cuff (14 cm in width * 84 cm in length) is warped around abdominal muscles below ribs which may cause to at least 60% restriction of blood flow detected by Power Doppler ultrasonography. All participants are instructed to perform ADIM both condition of BFR and BFR-free twice a week, for six weeks. Outcome measurements include Double leg lowering test (DLLT) for muscle strength, brightness mode ultrasound (USD) for muscle hypertrophy and electromyography (EMG) muscle activation. The same physical therapist will do the measurement at first week, third week and the sixth week.
This study expects to provide a new alternative way to improve the muscle activation, strength and activation of transverse abdominis in abdominal draw-in maneuver combined with blood flow restriction

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline double leg lowering test at 3,4,6 and 7 weeks
primary_outcome.description: initial position : 90 degrees of hip flexion with the knees extended maintain the pelvis in a posterior-tilted position while the extended legs are lowered Initial position is the subject maintain 90 degrees of hip flexion with the knees extended.Then the subject maintain the pelvis in a posterior-tilted position while the extended legs are lowered.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline electromyography at 3,4,6 and 7 weeks
primary_outcome.description: The surface electrodes will be placed 2 cm medial and inferior to the anterior superior iliac spine to record the activation amplitude of transverse abdominis.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline muscle thickness detected by ultrasound at 3,4,6 and 7 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Using the liner transducer, 5M-Hz, B(brightness)-mode and placed halfway on the midaxillary line between the iliac crest and the inferior border of the rib cage. It shows muscle thickness of external obliques, internal obliques and transverse abdominis.

arm_group.description: An inflatable cuff (14 cm in width * 84 cm in length) is warped around abdominal muscles below ribs which may cause to at least 60% restriction of blood flow detected by Power Doppler ultrasonography. All participants are instructed to perform abdominal draw-in maneuver both condition of BFR and BFR-free twice a week, for six weeks.

intervention.description: an inflatable cuff (14 cm in width * 84 cm in length) is warped around abdominal muscles below ribs which may cause to at least 60% restriction of blood flow detected by Power Doppler ultrasonography. All participants are instructed to perform abdominal draw-in maneuver.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Healthy subjects
- 20~35 years old
- BMI 18.5~24.99
Exclusion Criteria:
- Hypertension
- Have cardio-vascular disease
- Used to have abdominal operation or wound
- Have spinal surgeries or deformities
- Known neuromuscular or joint disease
- Pregnant
